newsitem.title: BRAZIL: Brazil 1995/96 soybean crop 96 pct sold - Safras.
newsitem.headline: Brazil 1995/96 soybean crop 96 pct sold - Safras.

text.p: Around 96 percent of Brazil's 1995/96 soybean crop was sold by last week, leaving only 885,000 tonnes still to be negotiated, said independent consultants Safras e Mercado in its weekly newsletter.
Of the remaining crop to be sold, 40 percent is in Rio Grande do Sul and 43 percent in Parana, it added.
The recent sharp fall in international prices is a strong reason for producers to hold back from making their final sales.
Buyers in the domestic market would like to pass on as much as possible the drop of around 17 percent in Chicago values from September's peaks to internal prices.
But given the domestic market is currently without offers, the impact of the fall has been partial as well as regionalised.
Prices in Rondonopolis in Mato Grosso have slipped six percent, Cascavel in Parana and Uberlandia in Minas Gerais seven percent and Passo Fundo in Rio Grande do Sul eight percent.
Only in Campo Grande in Mato Grosso do Sul has there been a more accentuated fall, reaching 12 percent in the past week.
Even so prices are still between 24 and 31 percent higher than in the corresponding period in 1995 and 30 to 35 percent up on the historical average of the past 10 years, Safras said.
Sales of the 1995/96 crop by October 17 per state as estimated by Safras are as follows in 1,000 tonnes and in percentage terms.
-- Caroline Bulloch, Rio de Janeiro newsroom, 5521 5074151
